slides.ocrText: Configuring Job Wizards

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe the architecture of job wizards
* Configure existing job wizard
* Create and modify job wizard steps
Job wizard basics

slides.originalNotes:
Job wizards
A job wizard has multiple screens, but only one screen is displayed at a time. The screens in a job wizard have an order (though it may be possible for a user to
traverse the screens out of order). Job wizards collect information and perform operations while guiding the user through a complex business transaction. The IJI functionality of job wizards are captured in a PCE The actual Job process is usually defined in a Gosu class which coordinates the policy transaction and the job wizards interacts with. So, SubmissionWizard is a but SubmissionProcess is Gosu.

The following IJI elements can be thought of as "building blocks“ that are used to render a job wizard-
Actions menu
Dependent steps
which are an ordered set of labels, each of which represents a single job wizard step screen. Some steps may not be accessible until a given step is complete-
Independent steps,
which are a set of labels, each of which maps to a single screen- Independent steps do not have a logical order and can be accessed at any time, regardless of what steps have been completed in the job wizard.
Tab bar, which is the set of tabs that run across the top of the application.  job wizard info bar, which lists information about the policy, the Account, or the Line of Business.
job wizard tool bar, which contains Back and Next buttons to navigate through the job wizard as well as other buttons relevant to the current step.
Screen , which contains the content for each step of the job wizard.

slides.originalNotes:
Comparing job wizards and location groups
The job wizards and location groups are similar in many ways.
slides.notes:
Comparing job wizards and location groups
The job wizards and location groups are similar in many ways.
slides.ocrText:
i Comparing job wizards and location groups G&G

¢ Both are assigned to a single tab
¢ Both reference multiple screens
¢ Both can have a set of screens that have no inherent order

¢ Both have a shared tab bar, info bar, actions menu, and side bar

slides.originalNotes:
Contrasting job wizards and location groups
A job wizard has some characteristics that a location group does not Have.

Wizard is a Location and it has no pages, but only screens-

The independent screens (such as the Policy Info, Drivers, and Vehicles screen in a Personal Auto submission) are accessible regardless of what step you are at in the wizard.

A distinction needs to be made between job wizardStep's available property and job wizardStep's visible property The visible property controls whether a job wizard Step appears or not This functionality is available to both wizard and non-wizard menu links- The available property controls whether a visible job wizard Step can be clicked on or not. This functionality is also available to both wizard and non-wizard menu links- The available  property controls whether a visible job wizard Step can be clicked on or not. This functionality is also available to both wizard and non-wizard menu links- However, availability for a job wizardStep is sometimes based on where a user is within the wizard. Location within a wizard does not typically change a job wizardStep's visibility-

slides.ocrText:
i Contrasting job wizards and location groups G&G

¢ Wizards have a toolbar specifically for navigating through the screens
¢ Wizards access screens directly (as opposed to using pages)
« Wizards have a set of screens which have an inherent order

¢ Wizard screen availability can be tied to where you are in the wizard

slides.originalNotes:
Job wizards in the base application
In PolicyCenter each job has a job wizard associated with it- For example, the most frequently used job wizard is the submission job wizard which has the SubmissionWizard.pcf file that contains the steps for collecting information about a submission- The wizard
prequalifies the applicant, collects policy information, performs risk analysis, reviews the policy, views a quote, prints forms, and sets up billing- Each wizard step has a screen such as the New Submission,  Qualification, Policy Info, Quote, and Submission Bound screens- Each screen is a set of PCF files that defines the screen and its component parts.  Some other wizards included in the base application are: 
Renewal Wizard Reinstatement 
Wizard
Policy Change
Wizard
Audit Wizard
Cancellation Wizard
Rewrite Wizard
Issuance Wizard –A submission may be bound, but its policy documents may not yet be issued because the insurer may need to collect or verify additional information. The mechanism that PolicyCenter uses to support this final step is the issuance policy transaction.

slides.originalNotes:
Job wizard architecture
The architecture of a job wizard is simpler than that of a location group- A job wizard’s architecture consists of job wizard steps, and each job wizard step points directly to a screen-

Often, job wizard steps are grouped together into wizard step sets or wizard step groups. Job wizard step sets let developers specify logic which is identical for multiple steps based on the lines of businesses.  For example, the submission wizard is often said to have a "sandwich-like“ structure.

The first and last steps are the same across all lines of business which are like the bread of a sandwich – remaining constant regardless the type of sandwich.

The interior steps vary dramatically depending on the line of business. A job wizard is a location  (IJI) and implements the functions that are a part of the entire job process-
slides.notes:

slides.originalNotes:
Job wizard properties: countsAsWork
Changes in a job wizard are always sent back to server and stored in the session and committed whether countAsWork is true or false. Difference is, if countAsWork is true then a quick link to the page will be created and added to the Unsaved Work menu. So you can quickly get to the pages you just modified- For example, link to Submission and its Offerings page are listed in the Unsaved Work menu because countAsWork property is set to true for Submission wizard.  Changes get committed when you navigate in a job wizard using the Previous and Next buttons. Once they are committed then the page is removed from the unsaved work queue- But if you navigate away by clicking the Desktop for example, unsaved work still stays in the queue in the Unsaved Work menu and the button appears green in the same user session-

Clicking on Save Draft button in a job wizard commits your work even if your countAsWork property is set to false so that you can reopen the job you saved in draft state later- In addition, if you log out or the system times out the user session when a  change has been made but not committed to the database yet,  PolicyCenter will not keep any Unsaved Work-
slides.notes:
Job wizard properties: countsAsWork
Changes in a job wizard are always sent back to server and stored in the session and committed whether countAsWork is true or false. Difference is, if countAsWork is true then a quick link to the page will be created and added to the Unsaved Work menu. So you can quickly get to the pages you just modified- For example, link to Submission and its Offerings page are listed in the Unsaved Work menu because countAsWork property is set to true for Submission wizard.  Changes get committed when you navigate in a job wizard using the Previous and Next buttons. Once they are committed then the page is removed from the unsaved work queue- But if you navigate away by clicking the Desktop for example, unsaved work still stays in the queue in the Unsaved Work menu and the button appears green in the same user session-

Clicking on Save Draft button in a job wizard commits your work even if your countAsWork property is set to false so that you can reopen the job you saved in draft state later- In addition, if you log out or the system times out the user session when a  change has been made but not committed to the database yet,  PolicyCenter will not keep any Unsaved Work-
slides.ocrText:
i Job wizard properties: countsAsWork G&G

¢ Allows a user to resume working in a wizard after leaving the wizard without
saving

¢ If set to true and user navigates away before finishing a wizard, wizard step is
listed as Unsaved Work in the same session

slides.originalNotes:
Job wizard properties: canVisit and canEdit
The can Edit property determines whether a user can edit the information in the job wizard. In some situations, you may want to let a user review the information entered in a job wizard at some previous point in time without being able to edit that information. The canVisit property determines whether a user can visit the job wizard.

For example, you would want a canEdit condition which returned false under the circumstance when an underwriter wants to view a policy submission that is bound. A bound submission cannot be edited because this would mean that a job is Complete.

The canVlsit property gives only view permission in case of submissions that are complete- Hence you do not see the edit buttons for a submission that is Bound but the edit submission buttons are complete- Hence you do not see the edit buttons for a submission that is Bound but the edit submission buttons are available to a submission in Draft state-
slides.notes:
Job wizard properties: canVisit and canEdit
The can Edit property determines whether a user can edit the information in the job wizard. In some situations, you may want to let a user review the information entered in a job wizard at some previous point in time without being able to edit that information. The canVisit property determines whether a user can visit the job wizard.

For example, you would want a canEdit condition which returned false under the circumstance when an underwriter wants to view a policy submission that is bound. A bound submission cannot be edited because this would mean that a job is Complete.

The canVlsit property gives only view permission in case of submissions that are complete- Hence you do not see the edit buttons for a submission that is Bound but the edit submission buttons are complete- Hence you do not see the edit buttons for a submission that is Bound but the edit submission buttons are available to a submission in Draft state-
slides.ocrText:
i Job wizard properties: canVisit and canEdit G&G

¢ lf canEdit evaluates to true, the job wizard is editable when in edit mode
* Some conditions include: edit permission, job state

¢ lf canVisit evaluates to true, the users can view the job wizard
* Some conditions include: view permission

* Examples:
¢ Users without edit permission cannot edit submissions in draft mode

« A bound (completed) submission is not editable, but may be viewable

slides.originalNotes:
Job wizard entry points and variables tabs
In the application, a new submission can be created using Actions menu, Submission Manager, and the Policy tab drop-down list After you select the line of business on the New Submission screen, the submission and policyperiod parameters are initialized. The type of job is checked and if the job type is Submission then the SubmissionWizard is started.

Locations can have multiple entry points. This is useful when a single location can be referenced from different places with different known pieces of information. For example, the SubmissionWizard can be accessed with two objects (as seen in the first entry point), or with three objects (as is the case in second entry point)-

Most navigation widgets have an action property, which defines where to naviqate to when the widget is clicked. The syntax for an action property which navigates to a location is: 
pcf.LocationEnttyPointmethod(objectList), where
     LocationEnttyPoint is (one of) the location entry point(s) defined on the destination location's Entry Points tab.
method is the  method used to navigate to the location (either "push" or "go")- 
objectList is a comma-delimited list of zero to many objects- This list must match the number of objects and the type which are expected by the location entry
     point-

For example, the Policy Summary under tools lists the Pending Policy Transactions The Transaction# has an action of
UJobForward-go(job)". The go method indicates that clicking the cell item should navigate the user to that location- The job type is passed into the parenthesis which in this case is Submission- (You can also leave the parenthesis empty depending on the number of arguments.) The location to navigate to is the one that has an entry point of

slides.ocrText:
i Job wizard entry points and variables tabs

¢ Entry point definition
* Syntax: EntryPointName(objectName1 : ObjectType1, objectName2 : ObjectType2 ... )
« Examples:

+ SubmissionWizard(submission : Submission, policyPeriod : PolicyPeriod)

+ SubmissionWizard(submission : Submission, policyPeriod : PolicyPeriod, wizardStep : String)
¢ Variables tab: Each object expected in all entry points must be declared here
¢ Navigating to a job wizard

* Syntax: EntryPointName.go(objectsToPass)

« Example: JobForward.pcf > SubmissionWizard.go(job as Submission, policyPeriod,
wizardStep)

slides.originalNotes:
WizardStepGroup
Wizard step groups have a visible property but they do not have an available property. Wizard step groups are intended for creating a collection of "child" steps or "sub" steps, as opposed to wizard step sets, which are intended to gather a set of steps which should be treated as a logic unit, for example, in terms of visibility or LOB specific steps.
slides.notes:
WizardStepGroup
Wizard step groups have a visible property but they do not have an available property. Wizard step groups are intended for creating a collection of "child" steps or "sub" steps, as opposed to wizard step sets, which are intended to gather a set of steps which should be treated as a logic unit, for example, in terms of visibility or LOB specific steps.
slides.ocrText:
i WizardStepGroup

A WizardStepGroup is a set of wizard steps which:

* are indented
« have a single parent label
* Example:
SubmissionWizard -> Policy Contract group

slides.originalNotes:
WizardStepSet and WizardStepSetRef
In the base application, there are sets of wizard steps for the submission wizard which change depending upon the line of business. For example, one set of wizard steps is used for personal auto submission and a different set of wizard steps for the workers comp submission.

The availability and visibility logic for a wizard step set is accessible in the properties window. The step set can use the mode property to select the line of business for the submission-
slides.notes:
WizardStepSet and WizardStepSetRef
In the base application, there are sets of wizard steps for the submission wizard which change depending upon the line of business. For example, one set of wizard steps is used for personal auto submission and a different set of wizard steps for the workers comp submission.

The availability and visibility logic for a wizard step set is accessible in the properties window. The step set can use the mode property to select the line of business for the submission-
slides.ocrText:
i WizardStepSet and WizardStepSetRef G&G

¢« AWizardStepSet is a set of wizard steps which have shared logic (visible,
available, mode) and can be inserted into a wizard directly or into a wizard group

« AWizardStepSetRef is a reference to the PCF where the step set is stored

slides.originalNotes:
Independent job wizard steps
Configuration of independent job wizard steps.
slides.notes:
Independent job wizard steps
Configuration of independent job wizard steps.
slides.ocrText:
i Independent job wizard steps

¢ To make a step independent, set its independent attribute to true
¢ The independent steps title and title icon are set in the job wizard widget
« Example

* SubmissionWizard -> Tools section

slides.originalNotes:
Order of job wizard steps
How is the order of job wizard steps determinedQ
slides.notes:
Order of job wizard steps
How is the order of job wizard steps determinedQ
slides.ocrText:
i Order of job wizard steps

Is determined by order in which they appear in PCF
* Job wizard displays all visible steps in order declared
« Dependent steps are always in top box
* Independent steps are always in bottom box

* Child steps of a job wizard step group are indented

slides.originalNotes:
Screens PCFs
Each job wizard step links to a screen PCF, which contains all the content, such as wizard buttons, title, step label, and widgets to collect data for that wizard step.
slides.notes:
Screens PCFs
Each job wizard step links to a screen PCF, which contains all the content, such as wizard buttons, title, step label, and widgets to collect data for that wizard step.
slides.ocrText:
i Screens PCFs

Screens are referenced by job wizard steps
¢ ScreenPropertyOfJobWizardStep = EntryPointOfScreen(objects ToPass)
Ascreen PCF contains references to all embedded content
Screen related labels
* Title determines the text displayed in the title bar of a screen
« Label determines the text displayed in the sidebar
Buttons on screen
« Wizard button (previous / next) behavior is handled automatically

* Toolbar buttons are displayed based on job type and status

* job wizards have toolbars used to navigate through the ordered screens.

* job wizard screens can have conditional availability tied to where you are at in the

Question G

,~ — Why would you want to put job wizard steps into a step group? A step

¢ set?
4

¢

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer G

ae my would you want to put job wizard steps into a step group? A step
’ ?
¢

You might put steps into a step set when you want to control the visibility or availability
of multiple steps with a single condition. You might put steps into a step group when
you want the steps to be indented with a single label displayed over all of them.

SS Se ee eee eo

Question G

_~ — What attribute controls the order of appearance of job wizard steps in the
o user interface?

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer G

,~ — What attribute controls the order of appearance of job wizard steps in the
oo user interface?

There is no attribute that controls the order of appearance. Order of appearance is
based on the order in which the wizard steps are listed in the PCF file.

SS Se ee eee eo

ae ee does a step behave differently if you set its independent attribute to
, ?
¢

Answer G

ae tae does a step behave differently if you set its independent attribute to
’ ?
¢

Setting a step’s independent attribute to true will list it at the bottom of the sidebar, and
it cannot be navigated to using the Back/Next toolbar buttons.

SS Se ee eee eo

Question G

,~ — What is a job wizard's entry point? What other elements of the user
¢ interface reference a job wizard's entry point?

4
¢

SS oe ee oe oe oo

Answer G

,~ — What is a job wizard's entry point? What other elements of the user
oo interface reference a job wizard's entry point?
¢

Ajob wizard's entry point is the internal name for the job wizard. It is used by
navigation widgets which navigate to the job wizard when clicked.
